Issues.Title: Safari's input[disabled] text is too faded
Issues.Body:
<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->

This is about **Bulma**.

### Overview of the problem

<!-- UNCOMMENT THE APPROPRIATE LINES -->

This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**.
I'm using Bulma **version** 0.7.2.
My **browser** is: Desktop Safari 11.1.2, iOS Safari 10.3.3.
I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate**.

### Description

Safari is rendering `disabled` input fields with faded text. 

Instead of the Bulma default `#7a7a7a` (48% luminosity), the input text renders at `#cecece` (81% luminosity).

### Steps to Reproduce

```html
<input disabled value="Some text" />
```

### Expected behavior

Text color would match across browsers.

### Actual behavior

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6340841/52501503-5d7b6480-2b95-11e9-8902-0c965f8ef960.png)


------------

Here's a StackOverflow documenting this issue (not Bulma specific): https://stackoverflow.com/questions/262158/disabled-input-text-color

It looks like one solution is patching [`sass/elements/form.sass`](https://github.com/jgthms/bulma/blob/ff8c4c18accf2c0094aa77945b1d2180ac927159/sass/elements/form.sass#L67):

```patch
input
  &[disabled],
  fieldset[disabled] &
+   -webkit-text-fill-color: $input-disabled-color
+   opacity: 1
```

Happy to submit a PR if welcome.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Safari's input[disabled] text is too faded" (#2355)

Issues.Title: Better Naming Suggestion for better RTL Support
Issues.Body:
<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->

<!-- Choose one of the following: -->
This is about **Bulma | the Docs**.

<!-- Is it about Bulma or about the Docs? -->
<!-- Is it a bug/feature/question or do you need help? -->
<!-- If it's a bug, is it a browser bug? -->

### Overview of the problem

<!-- UNCOMMENT THE APPROPRIATE LINES -->

This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**
<!-- This is about the Bulma **Docs** -->
<!-- I'm using Bulma **version** [x.x.x] -->
<!-- My **browser** is: -->
<!-- This is a **Sass** issue: I'm using version [x.x.x] -->
<!-- I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate**? -->

### Description

<!-- Description of the bug, enhancement, or question -->
There are many instances in Bulma that uses `is-right` and `is-left` in the classes which if you try to use a right to left language is rather confusing and hard to maintain.

### Proposal
I propose using `is-at-start` or `is-start` and `is-at-end` or `is-end` instead. There are two benefits in my opinion:
1. Start and end phrases are more semantic class names relevant to language direction.
2. I think it is very understandable since the same methodology is used in `flexbox`

### Final Note
I know it might be a huge change in the syntax but I believe in long run it helps more adoption of the Bulma in more languages.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Better Naming Suggestion for better RTL Support" (#2347)

Issues.Title: FR: Add modifier class to allow any arbitrary element to appear closer to a title (not just subtitle)
Issues.Body:
<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->

<!-- Choose one of the following: -->
This is about **Bulma**.

<!-- Is it about Bulma or about the Docs? -->
<!-- Is it a bug/feature/question or do you need help? -->
<!-- If it's a bug, is it a browser bug? -->

### Overview of the problem

<!-- UNCOMMENT THE APPROPRIATE LINES -->

This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**
<!-- This is about the Bulma **Docs** -->
I'm using Bulma **version** 0.7.2
My **browser** is: Safari 12.0.2 on macOS Mojave 10.14.2
<!-- This is a **Sass** issue: I'm using version [x.x.x] -->
I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate**.

### Description

Right now, when you have a title and a subtitle touching, the subtitle's margin-top will automatically reduce itself so that they are closer together. However, if you want to have supporting information close to a title, like tags, or a byline that would not make sense to be spaced as far as a normal paragraph would, you currently have to manually create that CSS.

A new modifier class that could be attached to any arbitrary number of items following a title-classed element that would make those elements appear closer to the title (or, indeed, a title + a subtitle) would help alleviate a lot of other manual work that would have to be done to, for instance, easily put things like tags or other elements underneath a title without technically making them subtitles.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "FR: Add modifier class to allow any arbitrary element to appear closer to a title (not just subtitle)" (#2346)

Issues.Title: Add -ms-flexbox vendor prifix for better IE10 support
Issues.Body:
<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->
<!-- DO NOT REBUILD THE CSS OUTPUT IN YOUR PR -->

<!-- Choose one of the following: -->
This is an **improvement**.
Add `-ms-flexbox` vendor prefix to `is-flex` related class 

### Proposed solution
According to [mozilla developer docs](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/CSS_Flexible_Box_Layout/Mixins) and [caniuse.com](https://caniuse.com/#search=flex), IE10 supports `flex` partially with `-ms-flexbox` vendor prefix, and this is how [bootstrap 4](https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap/blob/v4-dev/dist/css/bootstrap-grid.css#L1012) do as a fallback with their `d-flex` helper class, so I suppose it's not a bad idea to add it to `is-flex` classes?
